review.title: Mining Worse and Better Opinions. Unsupervised and Agnostic Aggregation of Online Reviews
review.abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel approach for aggregating online reviews, according to the opinions they express. Our methodology is unsupervised - due to the fact that it does not rely on pre-labeled reviews - and it is agnostic - since it does not make any assumption about the domain or the language of the review content. We measure the adherence of a review content to the domain terminology extracted from a review set. First, we demonstrate the informativeness of the adherence metric with respect to the score associated with a review. Then, we exploit the metric values to group reviews, according to the opinions they express. Our experimental campaign has been carried out on two large datasets collected from Booking and Amazon, respectively.

sections.heading: 2 Review Adherence to Typical Terminology
sections.text: We want to prove that positive reviews, as opposed to negative ones, generally correspond more closely to the emerging terminology of the entire review collection, and this will provide us with a form of alternative polarity detection: in fact, we could estimate the relative polarity of a review by measuring its conformity with domain terminology. As a meaningful comparison with terminology requires a considerable piece of text, the proposed approach best applies to a number of reviews. Here, we describe how the domain terminology is extracted and define a measure of how a text matches such terminology.

sections.text: The terms we use in this context are, in fact, very different (e.g. "monotonous" in the mathematical domain).The identification of this term is important for two main reasons: i) avoiding these irrelevant terms (such as "the," in "the...") have a weight in the calculation of adherence; ii) knowing which key terms are more relevant in a number of texts; and terminology is agnostic in a domain and language, with the advantage that it is not based on domain and linguistic resources.

sections.heading: 2.2 Adherence Definition
sections.text: The match (adh) of a document d with a terminology T is defined as: adhT (d) = | [[t | t] comes in d {t} | [t | t] in d} | (4) It represents the fraction of the terms in document d that belongs to the terminology T. This value will typically be much smaller than 1, since a document is likely to contain many non-substantive words that are not part of the domain terminology. However, the specific value of the match is of little interest to us: We show how more matches tend to be more positive than those with lower values of match, using the value only for comparison and not on an absolute scale.

sections.heading: 3 Datasets
sections.text: The first data set consists of a collection of reviews from the booking website, between June 2016 and August 2016. The second data set contains reviews from the Amazon website and it is a subset of the data set available at http: / / jmcauley.ucsd.edu / data / amazon, which were previously used in [14,15]. We also used a contrasting data set to extract the domain terminology.Booking Dataset. For the booking record we had 1,135,493 reviews, which relate to 1,056 hotels in 6 cities. We only took into account hotels with more than 1,000 reviews, in each language. For each review, we focused on: - a real value given to the hotel by the reviewer, at the interval [2,5,10]; - posContent: a text describing the hotel pros; - negative data set: a text describing the hotel accounts; - the name of the hotel that refers to.

sections.heading: 4 Experiments and Results
sections.text: Each record D is divided into categories Ci. Each category contains elements that we represent by the set of their ratings Ij. When we conduct experiments on D, we extract the terminology of each category Ci (TCi). Then we calculate adhTCi (r) for each r-Ij-Ci (r is the individual rating).For the Amazon record, Ci are the product categories, while Ij's are the products (represented by their ratings).For the booking record, Ci are the hotel categories, while Ij's are the hotels (represented by their ratings).We conducted experiments with and without ratings. The latter was taken into account to avoid bias: ratings with the highest ratings are over-represented in the data set, so the calculation of the terminology can be distorted into positive terms. Therefore, we randomly selected the same number of reviews for each Ci and for each rating.

sections.heading: 4.1 Adherence Informativeness
sections.text: An initial analysis examines whether there is a relationship between adherence to ratings - introduced in Section 2 - and the rating associated with each rating. Amazon Dataset. For each product category, we extract the reference terminology by balancing all ratings belonging to that category, for the appropriate language. Then we calculate the adherence value for each product category. To show the results in a meaningful way, we group ratings into 5 containers, depending on their rating, and calculate the average of adherence values in each waste bin. The results are shown in Figure 1. The figure shows a line for each product category. Overall, it highlights that higher adherence ratings imply better alignment with the reference terminology.

sections.heading: 4.2 Good Opinions, Higher Adherence
sections.text: Interestingly, the text of each review in the Booking Dataset is conveniently divided into positive and negative content. Therefore, we conduct an additional experiment by taking into account only positive and negative parts of the reviews. For each city, we group positive and negative content of the reviews and calculate the compliance value for each positive and negative part taking into account the reference terminology. Finally, we calculate the compliance values according to the review containers. The results are shown in Figure 5 for the unbalanced dataset. In the chart, we specify two lines for each city: the fixed (dashed) lines are obtained by taking into account the positive (negative) content of the reviews. The same color for fixed and dashed lines corresponds to the same city. We perform the same calculation by taking into account a balanced dataset (Figure 6). Both charts underline that there is a clear separation between the fixed and dashed lines. In particular, the average compliance, taking into account positive content is good for most of the containers (Figure 6).

sections.heading: 4.3 Extension to Different Languages
sections.text: The experiments described so far were conducted using a subset of reviews in English taken from the original booking data set, which also includes other languages. To further evaluate the validity of the metric, we selected two additional review sections in Italian and French. For each subset, we drew two charts, the first taking into account all the review content, the second taking into account the separation between positive and negative content. For these experiments, we considered unbalanced containers due to the limited number of reviews available in each language. The results are confirmed in Figure 7. Essentially, in both cases, the higher the score, the higher the adherence to the overall text is (Figure 7-a and Figure 7-c). Similarly, the charts in Figure 7-b and Figure 7-d show a clear separation between positive and negative adherence values when the score increases.

sections.heading: 4.5 Representative Terms in First and Last Bins
sections.text: Here we extract the most common terms in the positive and negative categories of reviews. In view of an element (either of a hotel or a product), we look at the terms contained in the positive sentence and in the negative sentence (last and first container, with Kbins = 10), which can also be found in the extracted terminology. For each term, we calculate the value of the term frequency inverse document frequency (tf-idf) (in this case, tf is the term frequency within the container, i.e. the number of reviews that contain such a term), sort the terms accordingly and select the first 20 terms for the positive and negative sentence. Then, we remove the two terms to identify the most discriminating ones. Table 11 shows the terms that are extracted for two Amazon products. After extracting the terms for each element, we calculate their frequency within an entire category. Again, we remove the terms that highlight the groups for both are common (negative and most representative for both categories).

sections.heading: 5 Related Work
sections.text: In this context, it should be noted that the approaches we have mentioned are counterproductive approaches, in which relevant candidates are identified by means of interdomain-specific contrast analyses [21,6,1]. Opinion Mining aims to automatically identify polarizations and sensations in texts [11], for example by filtering out subjective expressions that represent personal opinions and speculations [25] or uncovering so-called contextual polarizations of a word, i.e., the polarization that the word contextually traces back to the term.

sections.heading: 6 Final Remarks
sections.text: We presented a novel approach to aggregating assessments based on their polarity; the methodology did not require pre-marked assessments and knowledge of the area and language of assessments; we introduced the adherence metric and demonstrated its correlation with the review score; and finally, we relied on compliance with successfully aggregated assessments according to the opinions expressed.
